question_sets.context: One day we invited some friends to dinner. When it was about six o'clock, my wife found that we had little bread. So she asked our five-year-old daughter, Kathy, to buy some. "Here's a dollar," my wife said, " get two loaves(条) of bread, if they have it. If they don't have it, get anything. But hurry!" Kathy hurried off, and we waited and waited. By a quarter past six, all the friends had arrived. But Kathy had not returned. Finally we saw her dancing around the corner with a bright new hula hoop(呼啦圈) whirling(旋转) round her middle. "Kathy!" her mother cried. "Where did you get that hula hoop, and where is the bread?" "Well, when I got to the shop, they had sold all their bread," answered Kathy. "And you said 'If they don't have that, get anything!'"

questions.text: One day Kathy's parents invited some friends to <blank>.
questions.explanation: The passage states they invited friends to dinner, which is supper.

questions.text: How much did Kathy's mother give her?
questions.explanation: The passage mentions Kathy's mother giving her a dollar.

questions.text: Kathy <blank> in a hurry.
questions.explanation: The passage states Kathy hurried off, implying she went to the shop.

questions.text: What did Kathy buy at last?
questions.explanation: The passage mentions Kathy returning with a hula hoop.

questions.text: Why did she do this?

choices.A: because the shop had sold all their bread.
choices.B: because her mother asked her to get anything if they hadn't had bread.
choices.C: because she loved playing with hula hoop.

questions.explanation: Kathy explained she got the hula hoop because the shop was out of bread and she was told to buy anything.
questions.test_point: Reading Comprehension; Inference Skills; Cause & Effect

question_sets.context:
Zidane was born in Marseilles in the south of France in 1972. His parents were Algerian (阿尔及利亚人) and had moved to France in the 1950s. In 1989 at the age of 17 he joined Cannes football club. After three years he moved to Bordeaux in 1992 and was voted (被选为) "Young Player of the Year". In the same year he played in his first international match for France against the Czech Republic (捷克共和国). (1) He rescued (解救) the French team from disaster by scoring two goals near the end of the match. The final (决赛) score was 2 : 2.
In 1996 he moved to Italy to join Turin's team Juventus. He has played in three European Cup finals, twice for Juventus and once for Bordeaux. However, (2) he was not in any of the winning teams and did not play at his best in the three finals. Reporters describe him as one of the best midfield players (中锋) in the world. He can turn fast, he can run past the opposing team. (3) He can kick a ball onto just the right place for a team member to score. In his 33 games for France before the World Cup, he scored 10 goals.
Zidane is the hero of North African people who are living in France. These people have not had an easy life in the past. They are among the poorest of the country and find it hard to get jobs.
But the French team has at last shown the public that French people come from all over the world. Out of the 11 players, four were morn outside mainland France. Six other were born in France to non �C French parents. "France's win and (4) Zidane's playing has brought all French people together," said one reporter.
In the World Cup in 1998, Zidane played well against Saudi Arabia, but was sent off the pitch by the referee (裁判). (He stood on a Saudi Arabian player who had fallen over.) In the semi �C final against Croatia, (5) he was still not at his best. When the day of the match came, France's fans were rewarded. Zidane scored two out of France's three goals and was voted European Football of the Year. The President (总统) of France said on TV, "We're happy and that's the least I can say. It's the best day of my life."

question_sets.context:
Miss Grey lived alone in a small flat (公寓). She was old and did not like noise at all, so she was very pleased when the noisy man and woman who lived in the flat above moved out. A new young man moved in, and Miss Grey thought, "Well, he looks quiet."

But at three o'clock in the morning, Miss Grey was woken up by the barking (狗叫) of a dog.

She thought, "I've never heard a dog here before. It must belong to (属于) the new man in the flat above." So she telephoned the young man, and said some nasty (令人不愉快的) words to him about the dog, then hung the telephone up before he could answer.

Nothing more happened until three o'clock next morning. Then Miss Grey's telephone rang, and when she answered, a voice said, "I'm up to say that I haven't got a dog."

questions.text: How many people moved out the small flat?
questions.explanation: The passage states that 'the noisy man and woman' moved out.

questions.text: Who moved in the small flat?
questions.explanation: The passage mentions 'A new young man moved in'.

questions.text: What time was Miss Grey woken up by the barking of a dog?
questions.explanation: The passage states that 'at three o'clock in the morning, Miss Grey was woken up'.

questions.text: "I've never heard a dog here before." 这里I 指 <blank> .
questions.explanation: Miss Grey is the one who says, 'I've never heard a dog here before.'

questions.text: Which of the following is right according to the passage?

choices.A: Miss Grey lived in a flat with her son.
choices.B: Miss Grey liked the noise man, but didn't like the noise woman.
choices.C: The telephone woke Miss Grey up at 3:00 next morning.
choices.D: The young man said, "I have a big dog."

questions.explanation: The passage says 'Then Miss Grey's telephone rang...'.

question_sets.context:
At a quarter to six, Mrs Alison heard her husband park (停放) the car outside the house and at once went out to speak to him.
"What's the matter?" he asked. "You look upset (沮丧)."
"I have made a terrible mistake (错误), Jim," she said. "Mrs Johnson called me half an hour ago. We got talking and then without thinking, I asked her and her husband to come and have dinner with us this evening."
"Well, that's nothing to get upset about," Mr Alison said. "We will have a pleasant evening. We haven't seen the Johnsons for a long time."
"I'd like them to come," answered Mrs Alison. "but I've just found there is almost not any food in the house. You forgot to buy some steak (牛排). I asked you to get some on your way home from work three days ago."
"Steak?" Mr Alison said, "Oh, my dear,yes, I remember now. I did get some. You ought (应该) to have reminded (提醒) me about it. It's in the car. It's been there for the past three days!"

choices.B: went out to speak to her husband
choices.C: asked Mrs Johnson and her husband to come and have dinner
choices.D: found there was little food in the house

questions.explanation: Mrs. Alison was upset because she found there was little food in the house.

choices.C: at about a quarter past five

questions.explanation: Mrs. Johnson called Mrs Alison half an hour before Mrs. Alison spoke to her husband, which was at a quarter to six, so she called around half past five.

question_sets.context:
My friend Pedro works in the post office. He is a good sportsman, and he belongs to (属于) the Ajax Sports Club (俱乐部).
Three months ago, Pedro made a money-box. He got a flat(扁平的) box, and he coloured it white. He cut a slit (缝) in the top of the box. ( This slit was for money, of course. ) he wrote these
words on the box in big letters: WILL YOU HELP ?
That was all. He did not write his name, or any other name. The words were just ----- WILL YOU HELP?
Pedro took the money-box to the club. He put it on a table just inside the door. Every Friday evening he opens the box.
I do not belong to the Ajax Sports Club, but I went there last Friday evening with Pedro. He opened the money-box and took out the money. "Not bad," he said. "Between two and three pounds."
He closed the box and put it on the table. The money went into Pedro's pocket.
"People are kind," Pedro said. "They like to help. They like to give some money away."
"Are you going to keep the money?" I asked.
"Yes. I'm not a rich (富裕的) man, and that box is mine."
I said, "Doesn't anyone ever ask questions about it?"
"No. They help or they don't help. They never ask questions. People don't like to ask questions about money."

questions.text: Why does Pedro need the money?

choices.B: Because he is a poor man.
choices.C: He needs it for the club.

questions.explanation: Pedro says he is not a rich man and the box is his, indicating he needs the money.

questions.text: What does a money-box always (总是)have?
questions.explanation: A money-box always has a slit for putting money in it.

questions.text: How often does Pedro open the box?

choices.C: It is full, so he opens it.

questions.explanation: Pedro opens the box every Friday evening.

questions.text: Why does Pedro leaves the box near the club door?

choices.A: Because there is a table there.
choices.B: The club won't let him leave it in any other place.
choices.C: The door-man can look after it there.
choices.D: People are always coming and going, and they see it easily there.

questions.explanation: Although the text mentions that he put it on a table, the best answer is that people are always coming and going.

questions.text: People put money in the box. Who were they helping?
questions.explanation: Pedro keeps the money for himself, so they were helping Pedro.

question_sets.context:
A driver stopped his car on a street side to have a rest. As he lay down in the seat and closed his eyes(眼睛) ,a man came up and knocked at his window to ask the time. The driver opened his eyes and looked at his watch. "It's 8 am," he said. Then he went to sleep again. But soon he woke up because a second man was knocking at the window. "Sir, do you have the time?" he asked. The driver looked at his watch again, and told the man it was 8.30.
At this rate(如此下去) , he could not have a good rest, so he wrote a short note and put it up on the window for all to see. It said: "I don't know the time."
Again the man lay down in the seat for his sleep. A few minutes later a third man came along and began knocking at the window.
"Hey, sir. It's a quarter to nine."

choices.D: because there were many people in the street

questions.explanation: The driver stopped his car to have a rest because he was tired.

questions.text: Pedestrians (行人) came up and <blank>.
questions.explanation: Pedestrians came up and asked the time.

questions.text: The second pedestrian came to ask the time <blank>.
questions.explanation: The second pedestrian came to ask the time at half past eight.

questions.text: That day the man <blank> in the car.
questions.explanation: The man could not sleep because he was disturbed by pedestrians.

questions.text: What do you think the man should(应该) do to have a good rest?

choices.A: He should find a quiet place.
choices.C: He should put his watch outside the car.
choices.D: He should sleep under the car.

questions.explanation: To have a good rest, the man should find a quiet place.

They are very popular in the world. Chinese food has different tastes and is usually very delicious. It's also very popular in the world.

question_sets.context:
Animals, including insects, don't have a "language" like ours. They do not "talk" to each other in words and sentences. But if we watch them, we can see that they do have their ways of communicating with each other.
Can you see the rabbit's tail? When rabbits see this white tail moving up and down, they run away. They know that they are in danger. The rabbit has told them something without making a sound. It has given them a signal.
Many other animals use this kind of "language". When a cobra is angry, it raises its head and makes itself look fierce. This warns other animals. When a bee has found food, it goes back to its home. It cannot "tell" the other bees where the food is by speaking to them, but it does a little dance. This tells the bees where the food is.
Some animals "say" things by making sound. A dog barks, for example, when a stranger comes near. A cat purrs when it is pleased. Some birds make several different sounds, each with its own meaning. Sometimes we human beings speak in the same way. We make sound like "Oh" or "Ah" when we are frightened or pleased or when we drop something on our toes.

questions.text: Which one is true according to the passage?

choices.A: Animals do have a language like that of human beings.
choices.B: Bees communicate with each other by dancing.

questions.explanation: The passage mentions that bees use a little dance to communicate.

questions.text: A rabbit uses its tail to ________.

choices.A: warn other rabbits when they are in danger
choices.B: tell other rabbits where food is

questions.explanation: The passage states that rabbits run away when they see the white tail moving up and down, knowing they are in danger.

questions.text: When a cobra is angry, it ________.
questions.explanation: The passage mentions that when a cobra is angry, it raises its head and makes itself look fierce.

questions.text: Several different sounds can be made by a ________.
questions.explanation: The passage mentions that some birds make several different sounds, each with its own meaning.

questions.text: From the passage, we know that ______ use words and sentences to express ideas and thoughts.
questions.explanation: The first sentence indicates animals don't use language like human beings.

question_sets.context:
Perhaps you have heard a lot about the Internet, but what is it?
The Internet is many different networks around the world. A network is a group of computers put together. These networks joined together are called the Internet.
Maybe that doesn't sound interesting. But when we've joined the Internet. There are lots of things we can do. We can have a lot of interest on the World Wide Web (www). We can use the internet instead of a library to find all kinds of information for our homework.. We can find information about our favorite sports or film stars and do shopping on the Internet. We can also send messages to other people by e-mail. It is much cheaper and quicker than calling our friends or sending letters.
Thanks to the Internet, the world is becoming smaller and smaller. People can now work at home with a computer in front, getting and sending the information they need. They can buy or sell whatever they want by the Internet. But do you know 98%of the information is English? So what will English be like tomorrow?

questions.explanation: The passage is mainly about the Internet.

questions.text: The quickest and cheapest way for people to send message to their friends is <blank>.
questions.explanation: We can also send messages to other people by e-mail. It is much cheaper and quicker than calling our friends or sending letters.

choices.B: get some information about our favorite sports stars.

questions.explanation: The Internet can be used to find information for our homework, get some information about our favorite sports stars, and do some shopping, but not do some housework.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT true?

choices.A: The Internet is a big computer.
choices.B: The Internet is lots of computer networks.
choices.D: People can work at home with the help of the Internet.

questions.explanation: The Internet is many different networks around the world.

questions.text: What does the writer try to tell us with the last two sentences?

choices.A: The Internet is more and more popular.
choices.C: English is important in using the Internet.
choices.D: Every computer must join the Internet.

questions.explanation: 98% of the information is English, so English is important in using the Internet.

question_sets.context:
Chemists have been studying why people cry. They say the body produces two kinds of tears. One kind cleans out the eye if it gets dirt in it. But when people cry because of their feelings, these tears have poisonous chemicals in them. The body is getting rid of chemicals produced by strong feelings.
In the United States men have hearts diseases more often than women do. Doctors say heart disease and some other diseases have something to do with the pressure. Perhaps men suffer more from these diseases because they do not cry enough. And it is possible that as more and more women work outside their home, they will also suffer from more pressures. Then everyone will need to cry more.

question_sets.context:
Early to bed, early to rise, makes a man healthy, wealthy and wise.
This is an old English saying. Have you heard of it before? It means that we must go to bed early and get up early in the morning. Then we shall be healthy.  We shall also be rich (wealthy) and clever (wise).
This is true. The body must have enough sleep to be healthy. Children of young age should have ten hours' sleep every night. Children who do not have enough sleep cannot do their work very well. They will not be wise and they may not become wealthy!
The body also needs exercise. Walking, running, jumping, swimming and playing games are all exercise. Exercise keeps the body strong. Exercise also helps the blood (血液) to move around inside the body. This is very important. Our blood takes food to all parts of our body. The head also needs blood .Exercise helps us to think better!

questions.text: If we get up early and go to bed early , we'll <blank> .
questions.explanation: The passage mentions that going to bed early and getting up early makes a man healthy.

questions.text: If a child doesn't have 10 hours' sleep, maybe he <blank> .

choices.B: won't do well in his work

questions.explanation: The passage states that children who do not have enough sleep cannot do their work very well.

questions.text: A person needs exercise because <blank> .

choices.B: he has a lot of homework to do

questions.explanation: The passage indicates that exercise keeps the body strong and healthy.

questions.text: Exercise makes the <blank> move quickly and smoothly(流畅)
questions.explanation: Exercise helps the blood to move around inside the body.

questions.text: Which of the following if Not TRUE?

choices.A: Exercise does good to a person's head
choices.B: A student should have 10 hours' sleep
choices.C: It's good for you to get up early and go to bed early.
choices.D: If you have enough blood, you'll be wise.

questions.explanation: The passage does not claim that having enough blood will make you wise.

question_sets.context:
Mr. Scott is a veterinarian (兽医). He has the only clinic in the small town. The farmers near the town often ask him to treat(治疗) their domestic animals(家畜). There are a lot of people in his clinic and sometimes he's waken up late at night. So he's always busy and hopes to have a good rest.
One evening it was raining hard. When the last man left his clinic, he was too tired to stand. He went to bed after a quick supper. He looked at his watch and it was five to eleven and soon went to sleep. And at twenty past eleven the telephone bell woke him up. He told his wife to answer it. "Hello," said a man. "This is Mr. Ted here. May I speak to Mr. Scott please?" "Sorry, he went out half an hour ago , "answered Mrs. Scott. "I'm afraid he won't come back this evening. ""Something is wrong with my dog's eyes. But I don't know what to do. "Mr. Scott was afraid the man would bring his dog to his clinic. He asked his wife to answer the man on the phone as he said. Mr. Ted thanked her and then asked, "By the way, is the man lying by you qualified(有资格的) to treat my dog?"

questions.text: 1. Mr. Scott is always busy because <blank>.

choices.C: only he has a veterinary clinic in the town
choices.D: he knows the domestic animals well

questions.explanation: The passage states that he is always busy because he has the only veterinary clinic in the town.

questions.text: 2. Mr. Scott hurried to bed because <blank>.

choices.C: he was afraid to be sent for
choices.D: he would be waken up very soon

questions.explanation: The passage states that he was too tired to stand, so he hurried to bed.

questions.text: 3. Mr. Scott slept only for <blank> and the telephone bell rang.
questions.explanation: He went to bed at five to eleven and was woken up at twenty past eleven, which is about twenty-five minutes.

questions.text: 4. <blank>, so he asked his wife to answer the man instead.

choices.A: Mr. Scott wouldn't treat any animals that night
choices.B: Mr. Scott never goes out in the rain
choices.C: Something was wrong with Mr. Scott
choices.D: Mrs. Scott is also a good veterinarian

questions.explanation: Mr. Scott was pretending to be out so that he wouldn't have to treat any animals that night.

questions.text: 5. It seemed <blank>.

choices.A: Mr. Ted believed Mr. Scott's answer
choices.B: Mr. Ted didn't believe Mr. Scott's answer
choices.D: Mrs. Scott learned to treat domestic animals

questions.explanation: Mr. Ted asked if the man lying by her was qualified, implying he didn't believe Mr. Scott was out.

question_sets.context:
We have rather a small house, with only two bedrooms. You can think our alarm(恐慌),then, when Aunt Clara wrote to say that she was coming to stay with her family for the weekend. Her family, I should say, has four boys, all under the age of twelve.
I sent off a telegram(电报)at once, and explained(解释)in it that our house was too small. Aunt Clara called us up the next morning. "I forgot to explain," she said in her sweetest voice. "The boys will be bringing a couple of  tents(帐蓬)."
Even so my wife couldn't make free from fear(害怕). It was true that we had a large garden, but there was still the problem of feeding(喂养)four growing boys.
"And what if it rains?" she asked.
But Saturday morning turned out to be bright and clear when I went to the station to meet Aunt Clara. I tried to  squeeze (往车里塞)three of the boys, together with the luggage(行李), into the back of the car. The youngest sat in front, with Aunt Clara and me.
"I didn't see the tents among your luggage, " I turned over and said to David, the eldest boy.
"The tents!" said Aunt Clara. "Oh! We left them in the luggage van(行李车厢)".

questions.text: From the story, we know that the main problem was <blank>.
questions.explanation: The story mentions the small house and the number of people coming, indicating a problem with space.

questions.text: Aunt Clara <blank> after she received the telegram.
questions.explanation: The passage states that "Aunt Clara called us up the next morning."

questions.text: The boys were going to sleep <blank>.
questions.explanation: Aunt Clara mentioned the boys would be bringing tents, implying they would sleep outside.

questions.text: The man's wife <blank>.

choices.A: was looking forward to the visit.

questions.explanation: The passage mentions "my wife couldn't make free from fear(害怕)" and "And what if it rains?" she asked."

questions.text: Aunt Clare arrived by <blank>.
questions.explanation: The passage states that "I went to the station to meet Aunt Clara."

question_sets.context:
People eat different things in different parts of the world.
In south China we eat rice every day. Sometimes we eat it two or three times a day, for breakfast, lunch and supper. We usually eat it with fish, meat and vegetable.
The Japanese eat rice, too. They also eat a lot of fish. They sometimes eat raw(生的)fish. In Africa, maize(玉米)is the most important food. People there make maize into flour(面粉).From this flour they make different kinds of bread and cakes.
In western(西方的)countries such as Britain, Australia and the U.S.A, the most important food is bread or potatoes. People there usually make their bread from wheat flour. They cook the potatoes in different ways. In England the most popular food is fish and chips. Sometimes people cook this food at home, but usually they buy it at the shop. They eat this food at home, in their work place, in the park or on the road. People call it "take-away" food.

questions.text: This passage is about <blank>.
questions.explanation: The passage discusses the different types of food people eat in various parts of the world.

questions.text: Who sometimes eat fish when it isn't cooked?
questions.explanation: The passage states that "They sometimes eat raw(生的)fish" referring to Japanese people.

questions.text: The most important food for African people is <blank>.
questions.explanation: The passage says, "In Africa, maize(玉米)is the most important food."

questions.text: Which of the following countries is called " a western country"?

choices.A: One of the countries in Africa

questions.explanation: The passage mentions "In western(西方的)countries such as Britain, Australia and the U.S.A"

questions.text: People eat "take-away"food <blank>.
questions.explanation: The passage says, "They eat this food at home, in their work place, in the park or on the road."

question_sets.context:
My elder sister is an airhostess(飞机服务员). Yesterday morning my sister was at the back of the plane. She was going to take food and drinks to the passengers. A little old woman, who took on the plane for the first time, came up to her and said, "Could you tell me where the Ladies' Room is?"
"Certainly, Madam," answered my sister. "It is right at the other end of the plane in the front."
The old woman went too far. She walked all the way to the front of the plane, opened the door in front of her and saw the captain(机长) and his workmates in the small room. They were all busy with their work and didn't see her. She went out again and came back to my sister.
"Oh, did you find it?" asked my sister.
"Yes, I did," said the little old woman. "But there were four men in the Ladies' Room watching TV!"

questions.text: What does the writer's elder sister do?
questions.explanation: The first sentence states that the writer's elder sister is an airhostess.

questions.text: Who does she take food and drinks to?
questions.explanation: The passage mentions she was going to take food and drinks to the passengers.

questions.text: Why didn't the old woman know where the Ladies' Room was?

choices.A: Because she travelled by air for the first time.
choices.B: Because she wanted to walk with my sister.
choices.D: Because there weren't any toilets in the plane.

questions.explanation: The passage states that the little old woman took on the plane for the first time.

questions.text: Where did the old woman go?
questions.explanation: She opened the door and saw the captain and his workmates in the small room.

questions.text: What did the old woman think?

choices.B: My sister fooled the four men.
choices.C: The old woman thought she went to the wrong place.
choices.D: The four men watched TV in the Ladies' Room.

questions.explanation: The old woman said there were four men in the Ladies' Room watching TV.

question_sets.context:
When you are reading something in English, you may often meet with a new word. What's the best way to know it?
You may look it up in the English-Chinese dictionary. It will tell you a lot about the word: the pronunciation, the Chinese meaning and how to use the word. But how can you know where the word is thousands of English words? How to find it in the dictionary both quickly and correctly?
First, all the English words are arranged(安排) in the letter order. In the dictionary you can first see the words beginning with letter A, then B, C, D…. That means, if there are two words "desert" and "pull", "desert" will be certainly before "pull". Then if there are two words both beginning with the same letter, you may look at the second letter. Then the third, the fourth… For example, "pardon" is before "plough", "judge" before "just", etc.
Do you understand how to look up in the dictionary?
The dictionary will be your good friend. I hope you'll use it as often as possible in your English study.

questions.text: This passage is about______.
questions.explanation: The passage focuses on using an English-Chinese dictionary.

questions.text: In the dictionary you may not find_______.
questions.explanation: The passage mentions pronunciation, spelling, and usage, but not who used the word first.

questions.text: In an English-Chinese dictionary, the last word______.
questions.explanation: English words are arranged in alphabetical order, so the last word starts with Z.

questions.text: Which group of words is in the right order in an English-Chinese dictionary?
questions.explanation: The correct order is 'straight, subject, surprise'.

questions.text: In the passage the writer tries to tell us that_______.

choices.A: we have to use a dictionary when we read something in English
choices.B: an English-Chinese dictionary can tell us everything about a word
choices.C: an English-Chinese dictionary can help us a lot in our English study
choices.D: all English-Chinese dictionary are the same

questions.explanation: The writer highlights the helpfulness of an English-Chinese dictionary in English studies.

question_sets.context:
It was late on a snowing night. Doctor Van was driving fast to the hospital to do an operation on a badly hurt person. Minutes later he came to a red traffic light and had to stop to wait. A man suddenly opened the door of the car and got in.
"Drive on, " shouted the man, "Just do what I've told you to. " The man was strong and tall while Doctor Van was not.
"But I'm a doctor, " Van tried to tell him what he was going to do. "I'm on my way to the hospital to save. " "Stop talking and drive faster, as fast as you can! " the man stopped Van and Van had to do so.
Only a few minutes had passed when the man made Van stop his car again and drove him off, and he himself drove away very quickly.
Van stood in the snow for a moment and then walked around to look for a taxi. Another half an hour had passed when Van got out of the taxi and ran into the hospital. But it was too late and nothing could be done.
The man who had taken Van's car was standing by the person all the time. He was so sad! Only then did Van know that the man was the father of that badly hurt person!

questions.text: Who needed an operation at once?
questions.explanation: The passage states that Doctor Van was going to operate on a badly hurt person, and later reveals that the man was the father of that person.

questions.text: Why did the man take Van's car?

choices.A: Because he was a doctor and had to get to the hospital as soon as possible.
choices.B: Because he wanted to use the car to see a friend who was badly in hospital and needed his help.
choices.C: Because he wanted to get to the hospital earlier than the doctor.
choices.D: Because he was worried about his son and could not wait to see him.

questions.explanation: The passage implies that the man was desperate to see his son, who needed the operation.

questions.text: How long did it take Van to get to the hospital that night?

choices.D: We can't tell just from this passage.

questions.explanation: The passage says that 'Another half an hour had passed when Van got out of the taxi and ran into the hospital'. Along with the time he drove for the man, it took more than one hour.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true?

choices.B: Doctor Van was stronger than the man.
choices.D: The weather was not fine that night.

questions.explanation: The passage states that the man was strong and tall while Doctor Van was not.

questions.text: Which of the following can be the best title (标题) for this passage?

choices.B: A Good Doctor Met a Bad Man.
choices.D: How to save a Bad Hunt person.

questions.explanation: The title should reflect the main idea that the man's worry hindered the doctor from saving his son.

question_sets.context:
My friend, Dick, has a large police dog. It's name is Jack. Every Saturday afternoon Dick takes Jack for a long walk in the park. Jack likes these long walks very much.
One Saturday afternoon, a young man came to visit my friend. He stayed a long time. He talked and talked. Soon it was time for my friend to take Jack for a walk. But the man was still there. Jack became very worried. He walked around the room several times and then sat down in front of the man and looked at him. But the man kept talking. Finally Jack could_stand_it no longer. He went out of the room and came back a few minutes later. He sat down again in front of the man, but this time he held the man's hat in his mouth.

questions.text: From the story, we know that Jack is <blank>.
questions.explanation: The first sentence clearly states that Jack is a large police dog.

questions.text: Where does Dick walk with his dog every Saturday afternoon?
questions.explanation: The passage states that Dick takes Jack for a walk in the park every Saturday afternoon.

questions.text: Jack became very worried one afternoon because <blank>.

choices.A: he couldn't be taken out for a walk at the usual time.
choices.B: a young man came to visit Dick that afternoon.
choices.C: Dick walked around his room several times.

questions.explanation: Jack became worried because the young man's visit was delaying his usual walk time.

questions.text: What does the word "stand" mean in the passage?
questions.explanation: In this context, 'stand' means to endure or tolerate, indicating Jack's inability to tolerate the delay any longer.

questions.text: Why did Jack sit down again in front of the man with the hat in his mouth?

choices.A: Try to take the man laugh.
choices.B: Like the young man very much.
choices.C: Ask the young man to leave.

questions.explanation: Jack's action of bringing the hat was a way to prompt the man to leave so he could go for his walk.

question_sets.context: The best way of learning a language is using it. The best way of learning English is talking in English as much as possible. Sometimes you'll get your words mixed up ( 混合)and people will not understand you. Sometimes people will say things too quickly and you can't understand them. But if you keep your sense of humor (幽默感), you can always have a good laugh at the mistakes you make(你所犯的错误). Don't be unhappy if people seem to be laughing at your mistakes(错误). It is better for people to laugh at your mistakes than to be angry with you. because they don't understand what you are saying. The most important thing for learning English is : "Don't be afraid of making mistakes because everyone makes mistakes. "

questions.text: The writer thinks that the best way for you to learn a language is <blank>.
questions.explanation: The first sentence of the passage explicitly states that the best way to learn a language is by using it.

questions.text: What should you do in learning English?

choices.A: Be careful not to make any mistakes.
choices.B: Write as quickly as you can.
choices.C: Speak English as much as you can.

questions.explanation: The passage emphasizes the importance of speaking English as much as possible for effective learning.

questions.text: When people laugh at your mistakes, you should <blank>.
questions.explanation: The passage advises not to be unhappy if people laugh at your mistakes, suggesting that you should not care.

questions.text: When you make a mistake, you should <blank>.
questions.explanation: The passage encourages maintaining a sense of humor when mistakes are made, suggesting that you should laugh at them.

questions.text: The story tells us: "<blank>".

choices.A: Only foolish ( 愚蠢的 )people make mistakes
choices.D: There is no one who doesn't make mistakes

questions.explanation: The last sentence states that everyone makes mistakes, implying that there is no one who doesn't make mistakes.

question_sets.context:
Tom's father bought him a small shop, and Tom sold milk, butter, cheese, eggs and other things in it. His shop was in a small town, and it was open on Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, Friday, Saturday and on Sunday morning, but it was closed on Sunday afternoon and on Monday.
Tom went to some farms on Monday and bought their best butter, cheese and eggs from the farmers, but he brought his milk in the town. A truck brought them to his shop in the morning. Tom and his wife worked in the shop, and they sold a lot of food because it was good and clean.
Once a fat woman came into the shop on Saturday. She bought some eggs and some butter, and she said to Tom's wife. "Your eggs and your butter are dear today. Why are they dearer on Saturday and Sunday than on Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday and Friday?"
Tom's wife was unhappy. She looked at the fat woman and then she looked at Tom. But she did not give any answer. Then Tom smiled and said, "Our food is not dearer on Saturday and Sunday! It is cheaper on Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday and Friday!"

questions.text: Tom's shop was open <blank> a week.

choices.C: for five days and a half

questions.explanation: The shop was open Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, Friday, Saturday and Sunday morning, which equals five and a half days.

questions.text: What did Tom buy on Monday?
questions.explanation: The text states: 'Tom went to some farms on Monday and bought their best butter, cheese and eggs from the farmers.'

questions.text: Why could Tom sell a lot of food in the shop?

choices.A: Because they were kind to others.
choices.B: Because their food was good and clean.
choices.C: Because they got a lot of money.

questions.explanation: The text states: 'Tom and his wife worked in the shop, and they sold a lot of food because it was good and clean.'

questions.text: Tom's wife was unhappy because <blank>

choices.A: a fat woman said their eggs and butter were dearer on that day
choices.B: the eggs and the butter were not good on that day
choices.C: she didn't know how to answer the fat woman's questions
choices.D: Tom was not with her when the fat woman came

questions.explanation: The text says 'Tom's wife was unhappy' after the fat woman complained about the price.

questions.text: We can see from the text that Tom is very <blank>.
questions.explanation: Tom's response to the fat woman shows he is quick-witted and clever in handling the situation.

question_sets.context:
Once upon a time (从前) in Greece (希腊) there lived a clever man. His name was Aesop.
One day, when Aesop was taking a walk in the country , a man on the road stopped him. He said, "Kind sir, can you tell me how soon I can get to town?" "Go," Aesop answered.
"Of course I know I must go," said the man, " But I want to know how soon I can get to town." "Go," Aesop shouted to him again.
The man got angry. "He must be mad ," he thought. And he walked away. Suddenly he heard Aesop shouting at him, "You will get to town in two hours."
The man was in great surprise ? He turned back and asked, "Why didn' t you tell me that before?"
"How could I tell that before?" answered Aesop, "I didn't know how fast you could walk."

questions.text: One day Aesop was <blank>.

choices.C: taking a walk in the country

questions.explanation: The text states: 'One day, when Aesop was taking a walk in the country...'

questions.text: When the man asked Aesop the question, he <blank>.

choices.B: said that he couldn' t answer it
choices.C: told him that he was clever

questions.explanation: Aesop's first answers were simply "Go," which is not a direct answer to the man's question.

questions.text: From the text we know that <blank>.

choices.B: the man didn't know that place well
choices.C: the man knew how soon he could get to town
choices.D: the man knew Aesop very well

questions.explanation: The man needed to ask for directions, implying he wasn't familiar with the area.

questions.text: The man got angry because <blank>.

choices.A: Aesop said he wouldn't tell him anything
choices.B: he was very tired at that time
choices.C: he didn't get to know what he wanted
choices.D: it would take him two hours to get to town

questions.explanation: The man was frustrated because Aesop wasn't giving him the information he wanted.

questions.text: We can guess that at last the man felt very <blank>.
questions.explanation: The man's reaction to Aesop's final answer was surprise, as indicated by the text.

question_sets.context:
Mr Black worked for Mrs White. She was old, fat and rich. He worked in her garden . Mrs White did not know anything about the garden, but she always told him to do this or not to do that. This made Mr Black very angry . So he called her an elephant. Of course Mrs White was not pleased to hear that. She took Mr Black to the judge . The judge heard the story and said, "Mr Black, it is wrong to call a lady an elephant. You must never do that again. "
"You're right, " said Mr Black. "Do you mean that I must not call this lady an elephant?" "That's right, " the judge answered. "And can I call an elephant a lady?" asked the man. "Yes, you may, " the judge answered.
Mr Black looked at the lady. He still thought her to be an elephant, but he said, "Good-bye, lady. "

questions.text: Who wanted to go to the judge?
questions.explanation: The text states: 'She took Mr Black to the judge'. This implies Mrs. White wanted to go to the judge.

questions.text: Who knew more about the garden work?
questions.explanation: The text states: 'Mrs White did not know anything about the garden...', while Mr. Black worked in her garden.

questions.text: Is there an elephant in the woman's garden?
questions.explanation: The story uses 'elephant' as an insult, not as a literal animal in the garden.

questions.text: Why was Mr Black angry?

choices.A: Because Mrs White always told him to do a lot of garden work.
choices.B: Because Mrs White did not tell him to do the right thing.
choices.C: Because Mrs White called him an elephant.
choices.D: Because he did not like to work for Mrs White.

questions.explanation: The text states: 'Mrs White did not know anything about the garden, but she always told him to do this or not to do that. This made Mr Black very angry'.

questions.text: Which of the following is right?

choices.A: Mr Black knew it was wrong to call a lady an elephant and he was sorry.
choices.B: Mr Black said "Good-bye, lady" to Mrs White because he knew he was wrong.
choices.C: Mr Black said "Good-bye, lady" to Mrs White, but he thought her an elephant.
choices.D: Mrs White was very happy at last.

questions.explanation: The text states: 'He still thought her to be an elephant, but he said, "Good-bye, lady."'.

question_sets.context:
There is one language(语言), and people , young and old , men and women , use it very often , in every country in the world . It is everyone's second language .You can't hear it but it is very easy to understand(理解). It is sign(手势)language .
When you wave(招手)to a friend in the street , you are using sign language . When you put up your hand in class , you are saying " Please ask me , I think I know the right answer ." When a policeman wants to stop cars or buses , he puts up his hand . He's using sign language . Churchill's(丘吉尔)famous " V for Victory(胜利)" is also sign language . Sign language is useful(有用的)in quiet places or places full of noise(吵闹声). Even when you are swimming with your friends , you can have a talk under water .

questions.text: <blank> in the world use sign language ?
questions.explanation: The passage states that 'people, young and old, men and women' use sign language, which implies 'many people'.

questions.text: You can't hear sign language because it's <blank> language.
questions.explanation: The passage says, 'You can't hear it,' and indicates it's easy to understand, implying it's not spoken but visual.

questions.text: When you put up your hand in class , you mean <blank>.

choices.B: you want to ask a question

questions.explanation: The passage states, 'When you put up your hand in class, you are saying 'Please ask me, I think I know the right answer.'

questions.text: In a noisy(吵闹的)place the best way(方式)to talk is to <blank>.

choices.C: speak in a low voice(小声)

questions.explanation: The passage mentions, 'Sign language is useful in quiet places or places full of noise'.

questions.text: Which of the following is TURE ?

choices.B: Only Churchill used " V for Victory " .
choices.D: To nod one's head(点头)isn't sign language

questions.explanation: The passage indicates that sign language is a second language used by many people worldwide, implying it's used often.

question_sets.context:
Mozart was born on January 27 , 1756 and died(死)on December 5 , 1791 . When he was three , he often had music lessons with his older sister . His father took him through many different countries where he played music for lots of people .
But some people didn't believe that a little boy could write such beautiful music . They asked him to stay in a room all by himself for a week and somebody watched the room all the time . In the week , he finished a new piece of music After that , people believed that he could write beautiful music .
Mozart died when he was still a young man . During his short life he studied music and taught music and played music and wrote music . Though he worked so hard , he couldn't make much money . Often he had to borrow(借)money from his friends . But his music made him happy and for more than two hundred years his music has made other people happy , too .

questions.text: When he was <blank>, Mozart took music lessons with his sister.
questions.explanation: The passage states, 'When he was three, he often had music lessons with his older sister'.

questions.text: Some people asked Mozart to stay in a room all by himself in a week because they wanted to <blank>.

choices.A: let Mozart write a piece of music alone(单独)
choices.C: keep quiet so Mozart could write music quickly
choices.D: let Mozart have a good rest

questions.explanation: The passage mentions that people didn't believe Mozart could write beautiful music, so they asked him to stay in a room to see if he could write a new piece of music alone.

questions.text: Mozart lived <blank>.
questions.explanation: The passage states, 'Mozart died when he was still a young man,' indicating he lived a short life.

questions.text: Mozart worked hard and was famous , but he was <blank>.
questions.explanation: The passage says, 'Though he worked so hard, he couldn't make much money. Often he had to borrow money from his friends', implying he was poor.

questions.text: His music made <blank> happy.
questions.explanation: The passage indicates, 'But his music made him happy and for more than two hundred years his music has made other people happy, too'.

question_sets.context:
Air is all around us. At the time we are born, air is around us everywhere(任何地方). We live in air.
All living things need air. Living things cannot live without(没有)air. We can go without food or water for a few days, but we can't live a few minutes without air. We take in air. When we are working, we need more air. When we are sleeping, we need less air.
We live in air but we cannot see it. We can only feel it. We can feel it when it is moving. Moving air is called wind. How can you make air move? Here is one way. Take an open book in your hands in front of your face. Close it quickly. What can you feel? It is air.

questions.text: Where is air?
questions.explanation: The first sentence of the passage states that 'Air is all around us'.

questions.text: What do all living thing need?
questions.explanation: The second paragraph states that 'All living things need air'.

questions.text: Moving air is called <blank>.
questions.explanation: The third paragraph states that 'Moving air is called wind'.

questions.text: When do we need more air?
questions.explanation: The second paragraph states that 'When we are working, we need more air'.

questions.text: What does the word "less"in the passage mean?
questions.explanation: "less" means "少量"(a small amount) in Chinese.

question_sets.context:
Once upon a time, there lived a rich man. He had a servant(仆人). He and the servant loved wine(酒) and good food very much. Each time the rich man left his home, the servant would drink the wine and eat up all the nice food in the house. The rich man knew what his servant did , but he had never caught his servant doing that.
One morning, when he left home, he said to the servant, "Here are two bottles of poison(毒药)and some nice food in the house. You must take care of (看管好)them." With these words, he went out.
But the servant knew that the rich man had said was untrue(假的), after the rich man was away from his home, he enjoyed a nice meal. Because he drank too much, he was drunk and fell to the ground. When the rich man came back, he couldn't find his food and his wine. He became very angry. He woke (叫醒)the servant up. But the servant told his story very well. He said a cat had eaten up everything. He was afraid(害怕) to be punished(被惩罚), so he drank the poison to kill(杀死) himself.

questions.text: In the story, __________ liked wine and good food very much.
questions.explanation: The first paragraph states 'He and the servant loved wine and good food very much', which means both the rich man and the servant liked wine and good food.

questions.text: The rich man knew that it was ______ that drank the wine and ate up all the nice food.
questions.explanation: The first paragraph states 'The rich man knew what his servant did'.

questions.text: The rich man told the servant that there was poison in the two bottles, because_____.

choices.A: there was in fact poison in the bottles
choices.B: he did not want the servant to drink his wine
choices.C: he wanted to kill the cat
choices.D: he wanted to kill the servant

questions.explanation: The rich man lied to the servant so the servant wouldn't eat the food and drink the wine.

questions.text: In fact________ ate all the nice food and drank the wine.
questions.explanation: The third paragraph states 'he enjoyed a nice meal. Because he drank too much, he was drunk and fell to the ground', indicating the servant ate and drank.

questions.text: From the story, we know that the servant is very ____________.
questions.explanation: The servant lied to the rich man, so the servant is clever.

question_sets.context: One day a man went home and said to his wife, "I bought something for you. " "Thank you! " said his wife. " What have you bought for me?" "I've bought a gold ring (金戒). Here it is." He took it out for his wife to see. Then he dropped it to the ground. He began to look for it on the ground, but it was dark in the house and he could not see anything. Then he went out and began to look for it in the street. Just then a friend came along. " What's the matter with you?" asked his friend. " I am looking for my ring. I lost it just now." said the man. " Where did you lost it?" " I lost it in my house." " You lost your ring in your house, but you are looking for it in the street. How foolish it is!" " Ah," said the man, " But it is dark in my house. I shall never find it there. Bet here in the street, it is much brighter, I can see everything."

questions.explanation: The first sentence of the passage says that the man bought something for his wife. So, the answer is B.

questions.text: He lost his ring <blank> .
questions.explanation: The man told his friend that he lost it in his house. So, the answer is B.

questions.text: <blank> the man was looking for the ring, his friend came up.
questions.explanation: The passage says 'Just then a friend came along'. So, the answer is C.

choices.A: he lost it in the street
choices.B: it was much brighter in the street
choices.D: he wanted someone to help him

questions.explanation: The man said 'But it is dark in my house. I shall never find it there. But here in the street, it is much brighter, I can see everything.'. So, the answer is B.

questions.text: The friend thought the man was <blank> .
questions.explanation: The friend said 'You lost your ring in your house, but you are looking for it in the street. How foolish it is!'. So, the answer is D.

question_sets.context:
George liked flying a plane. Once he bought a small plane and learned how to fly it. He soon became so good that he could make his plane do all kinds of tricks(技巧).
George had a friend. His name was Peter. One day George said to his friend, " Peter, would you like to have a trip in my plane?" Peter thought, " I've traveled in a big plane several times, but I've never been in a small one, so I'll go."
They went up, and George flew around for half an hour and did all kinds of tricks in a shaken voice(颤抖的声音), " Well, George, thank you very much for these two trips in your plane."
George was very surprised and asked, " Two trips? "
"Yes, my first and my last." Answered   Peter.

choices.B: George was good at flying his plane
choices.C: he had never traveled in a small plane
choices.D: Peter could do all kinds of flying tricks

questions.explanation: Peter thought, " I've traveled in a big plane several times, but I've never been in a small one, so I'll go.". So, the answer is C.

questions.explanation: The passage says 'George flew around for half an hour'. Half an hour is 30 minutes. So, the answer is C.

questions.explanation: Peter said 'Yes, my first and my last.' which indicates only once. So, the answer is A.

questions.explanation: The passage says 'George flew around for half an hour and did all kinds of tricks in a shaken voice'. This indicates Peter was scared. So, the answer is D.

question_sets.context:
A habit (习惯)is something we do very often. We do not think when we are doing it. We can have good habits or bad habits.

Early to bed, early to rise, makes a man healthy, wealthy(富有)and wise (聪明).

This is an old English saying(谚语). Have you heard it before? It means that we should go to bed early and get up early in the morning. If we do like this, we shall be healthy, rich and clever.

Is this true? Perhaps it is. The body must have enough sleep. Young people of your age need eight hours' sleep every night. If you do not go to bed early, you can not have enough sleep. Then you can not think properly(合适地)and you can not do your work properly. You will not be wise and you may not become wealthy!

Some people go to bed late at night and get up late in the morning. This is not good for them. We must sleep at night when it is dark. The darkness helps us to sleep quickly. When the daylight comes, we must get up. This is the time for exercise. Walking, running, jumping, swimming, playing games are all exercise. If the body is not used, it becomes weak(虚弱). Exercise keeps it strong.

Our bodies also need air to breathe(呼吸). Without air we will die. We must have plenty of clean, fresh air to breathe, if we want to be healthy.

questions.text: A habit is something we are doing <blank>.
questions.explanation: According to the first sentence of the passage, a habit is something we do without much thinking about it.

questions.text: As it is said, if we want to be healthy, wealthy and wise, we must go to bed <blank> and get up <blank>.
questions.explanation: According to the second paragraph, we must go to bed early and get up early.

questions.text: Young people of your age need <blank> sleep every night.
questions.explanation: According to the third paragraph, Young people of your age need eight hours' sleep every night.

questions.text: We must have plenty of clean, fresh air to breathe <blank> we want to be healthy.
questions.explanation: If means '如果' here.

questions.text: Which word doesn't mean "wise"? <blank>.
questions.explanation: Foolish means silly.

question_sets.context:
Tom's father bought him a small shop, and Tom sold milk, butter, cheese, eggs, and other things in it. His shop was in a small town, and it was open on Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, Friday, Saturday, and on Sunday morning, but it was closed on Sunday afternoon and on Monday.
Tom went to some farms on Monday and bought their best butter, cheese, and eggs from the farmers, but he brought his milk in the town. A truck brought them to his shop in the morning. Tom and his wife worked in the shop, and they sold a lot of food because it was good and clean.
Once a fat woman came into the shop on Saturday. She bought some eggs and some butter, and she said to Tom's wife, "Your eggs and your butter are dear today. Why are they dearer on Saturday and Sunday than on Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, and Friday?"
Tom's wife was unhappy. She looked at the fat woman and then she looked at Tom. But she did not give any answer. Then Tom smiled and said, "Our food is not dearer on Saturday and Sunday! It is cheaper on Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, and Friday!"

question_sets.context:
Once upon a time (从前) in Greece (希腊) there lived a clever man. His name was Aesop.
One day, when Aesop was taking a walk in the country, a man on the road stopped him. He said, "Kind sir, can you tell me how soon I can get to town?" "Go," Aesop answered.
"Of course I know I must go," said the man, "But I want to know how soon I can get to town." "Go," Aesop shouted to him again.
The man got angry. "He must be mad," he thought. And he walked away. Suddenly he heard Aesop shouting at him, "You will get to town in two hours." The man was in great surprise. He turned back and asked, "Why didn't you tell me that before?"
"How could I tell that before?" answered Aesop, "I didn't know how fast you could walk."

questions.explanation: Aesop's first answers were just "Go,", which didn't directly answer the man's question about time.

choices.D: the man knew Aesop very well

question_sets.context:
Mr. Black worked for Mrs. White. She was old, fat, and rich. He worked in her garden. Mrs. White did not know anything about the garden, but she always told him to do this or not to do that. This made Mr. Black very angry. So he called her an elephant. Of course, Mrs. White was not pleased to hear that. She took Mr. Black to the judge. The judge heard the story and said, "Mr. Black, it is wrong to call a lady an elephant. You must never do that again."
"You're right," said Mr. Black. "Do you mean that I must not call this lady an elephant?" "That's right," the judge answered. "And can I call an elephant a lady?" asked the man. "Yes, you may," the judge answered.
Mr. Black looked at the lady. He still thought her to be an elephant, but he said, "Good-bye, lady."

questions.explanation: The text says, "She took Mr. Black to the judge."

choices.C: Because Mrs. White called him an elephant.
choices.D: Because he did not like to work for Mrs. White.

questions.explanation: The text says, "Mrs. White did not know anything about the garden, but she always told him to do this or not to do that. This made Mr. Black very angry."

choices.C: Mr. Black said "Good-bye, lady" to Mrs. White, but he thought her an elephant.
choices.D: Mrs. White was very happy at last.

questions.explanation: The text says, "He still thought her to be an elephant, but he said, 'Good-bye, lady.'"
questions.test_point: Reading Comprehension; Inference Skills; Character Analysis

question_sets.context:
Once there was a man who had two children, a boy and a girl. The boy was good-looking but the girl was not.
One day they found a mirror for the first time and they saw what they looked like. The boy was very pleased and he said to his sister, 'How handsome I am! I look much nicer than you!'
The girl did not like what her brother said and gave him a hard push. 'Go away!' she said.
Their father saw what was happening. He when up to them and said to the boy, 'You must always BE good as well as LOOK good.'
Then to the girl he said, 'My dear, if you help everyone and do your best to please him everyone will love you. It does not matter that you are not as good-looking as your brother.'

question_sets.context:
Scientists are trying to make the deserts(沙漠)into good again. They want to bring water to the deserts, so people can live and grow food. They are learning a lot about the deserts. But more and more of the earth(地)is becoming deserts all the time. Scientists may not be able to change the deserts. Scientists think that people make deserts. People are doing bad things to the earth.
Some places on the earth don't get very much rain, But they still don't become deserts. This is because some green plants are growing there. Small green plants and grass are very helpful to dry places. Plants don't let the hot sun make the earth even drier. Plants don't let the wind blow the earth(泥土) away, When a little of rain falls, the plants hold the water. Without plants, the land can become a desert much more easily.

questions.text: Why can the land become a desert?

choices.A: Some places don't get very much rain.
choices.B: Plants don't let the hot sun make the earth even drier.
choices.C: People don't keep the earth well.
choices.D: Scientists haven't learnt enough about the deserts.

questions.explanation: The passage implies that people's actions contribute to desertification, suggesting they aren't taking care of the Earth.

questions.text: Scientists <blank> to make the deserts into good land again.
questions.explanation: The passage states scientists are "learning a lot about the deserts" to try to improve the land.

choices.A: The land never stops becoming deserts.
choices.B: Scientists ask people to live in the deserts and grow food there.
choices.C: People do bad things to the earth.
choices.D: Scientists may not be able to change the deserts.

questions.explanation: The passage doesn't say that scientists ask people to live in the deserts. It says scientists want to bring water to the deserts, so people *can* live and grow food.

questions.text: Why are green plants and grass helpful?

choices.B: They can stop the wind from blowing the earth away.
choices.C: They can keep the earth wet(湿的)

questions.explanation: The passage mentions that plants hold water, protect against wind erosion, and help keep the earth from becoming drier.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best title(题目) for the passage(短文)?

choices.D: The Desert, the Tree and the Water

questions.explanation: The passage primarily discusses the issue of desertification and attempts to combat it, making "The Desert Problem" the most appropriate title.

question_sets.context:
Bruce and his other two friends, Bruno and Dick lived in the same city in England. They were free in their summer holiday. So they came to a village by a large lake. They liked fishing very much. Then the next day after they got there, they got to a boat and went fishing in the lake. They boated farther and farther. They came to an out-of-way place. They were very happy because there were a lot of fish. When it was time for them to go home, Bruce said to his friends: "We'd better make a mark here so that we will easily find the place tomorrow."
"You're right." Bruno said happily ."Let me do that."
"How foolish," said Bruce. "If it rains tonight, the rain water will wash the line off, and how can we find the mark tomorrow. You must cut a line with your knife."
Dick came up to them and said angrily. " Neither of you is clever. How can we find the place if we have another boat tomorrow? We should not go back tonight."

questions.explanation: Bruce thought it was not useful.

questions.explanation: Dick suggested not going back tonight.

question_sets.context:
A woodcutter(伐木工) was working in the forest one day when he found a box full of gold coins. Unfortunately, his wife was the kind of woman who could not keep a secret. Somehow, he knew, he had to prevent(阻止) her from talking about the gold.
He thought about this for a long time, then had an idea.
"I found something in the forest", he told his wife, "come with me and I'll show you." His wife followed him into the forest and soon they came to a tree. "Look at that!" the woodcutter said to his wife, and pointed to the tree. "There's a fish growing on that branch!" His wife was surprised, especially when he climbed up the tree and brought down the fish for her to see. They walked on and soon came to the river. "I'll just pull in my net and see what I've caught", the woodcutter said.
He pulled in his net and inside there were several hares(野兔). "How interesting!" he said "there are now hares in the river." After that, they came to where the woodcutter had found the box of gold. "Look, wife", he said "this is what I have found. A box of gold coins."The next day, his wife could not stop herself from telling her friends about all the wonderful things she had seen. Of course, nobody believed her!

choices.C: Hares often live in the river.

questions.explanation: The woodcutter was very clever.

question_sets.context:
People in our part of the country like living in caves(窑洞,山洞). It is a nicer and better living space than an ordinary (普通的,平常的)house. It's warm in winter and cool in summer.
There are two kinds of caves, earth ones and stone ones. The earth caves are dug(挖)into the hill side. The first thing to do is to find a place with the right kind of soil. The soil should be of good quality(质量). Earth caves don't last well. Usually they last only thirty years.
Stone caves are better and stronger. They are more expensive to build than both earth caves and ordinary houses. An ordinary houses won't go more than thirty years without major repairs. A stone cave will last four or five hundred years. It doesn't need major repairs. Sometimes you need just some paper, wood or paint for windows and walls.
People live in caves can enjoy the beauty of the nature all year round.

question_sets.context:
Do you know how to write an English letter?
When we write a letter in Chinese, we always put the date at the end of the letter. But it is different in English. We have to putiton on the top of the right corner. And above the date, we also write the number of our house and the names of our street, city and country. To begin the letter, we always use words like "Dear sir" "Dear Mr/ Miss/ Mrs …" To the end of the letter, we usually use words like "Yours" "Yours ever" or "Truly yours".
It is also different to write an English_envelope_(信封). If you write to an Australian friend named Jane Shute, write your name and address on the top of the left corner and write hers in the middle.
Now read the following envelope, please.
STAMP
Qin Ling
No. 11 Middle School
Ningbo, Zhejiang
China
Miss Jane Shute
65 King Street, New Town
Sydney, Australia

choices.D: at the top of the letter on the right

questions.explanation: The passage says that 'above the date, we also write the number of our house and the names of our street, city and country'.

question_sets.context:
Six people were traveling in a_compartment_(包箱 ) on a train. Five of them were quiet and_well behaved _(举止文明), but the sixth was a_rude_(粗鲁 ) young man who was making a lot of trouble to the other passengers.
At last, this young man got out at a station with his two heavy bags. No one helped him, but one of them waited until the rude young man was very far away , and then opened the window and shouted to him, "You left something behind in the compartment!" Then he closed the window again.
The young man turned around and hurried back with his two bags. He was very tired when he arrived, but he shouted_through _(通过 ) the window, "What did I leave behind?"
As the train began to move again , the passenger who called him back opened the window and said, "A very bad_impression_(印象)!"

choices.A: five of them were rude and badly behaved

question_sets.context:
The students were having their chemistry(化学)class. Miss Li was telling the children what water was like. After that, she asked her students, "What's water?" No one spoke for a few minutes. Miss Li asked again, "Why don't you answer my question?Didn't I tell you what water is like?"
Just then a boy put up his hand and said, "Miss Li, you told us that water has no colour and no smell. But where to find such kind of water?The water in the river behind my house is always black and it has a bad smell." Most of the children agreed with him.
"I'm sorry, children." said the teacher, "Our water is getting dirtier and dirtier. That's a big problem."

questions.explanation: The second sentence indicates that Miss Li was telling the children what water was like.

questions.explanation: The boy said the water in the river is always black.

questions.explanation: Most of the children agreed with him.

questions.text: The water in the river has colour and smell because it is getting <blank> .
questions.explanation: Our water is getting dirtier and dirtier.

question_sets.context:
Wang was born into a rich family in America, but he was not a spoiled child. His parents made him practice violin for hours every day and he also learned Karate (空手道)! To make pocket money, Wang had to deliver (发送) newspapers.
At five or six every morning, Wang was already up. Even on cold winter days, he rode his bike to deliver newspapers to every home!
"When I went outside, other people were not up yet," he said.
The best moment of his day, he said, was after he got home, tired and hungry, and ate sweet pies his mum had made.

questions.explanation: At five or six every morning, Wang was already up.

question_sets.context:
One of this summer's hottest books is "That Guy Was Cool." Sounds like a great book for kids, doesn't it? But parents and teachers want to read this one, too. It can teach them something about the language of today's kids.
So lots of people, young and old, went to see the book's author, 19-year-old Korean girl Guiyeoni, on Saturday. She was in Beijing to sign books for her fans.
"Guiyeoni wrote a story that is near to us and goes to our hearts," said a Junior 2 student in Beijing. "When I read it, I laughed and I cried."
Like the "Meteor Garden" TV series, "That Guy Was Cool" tells an unusual story of love between two students. The girl is sweet, but she's just average(一般的). The boy is good-looking and has everything, but he is often unhappy because his father died when he was very young. They become close and help each other to be happy. In the end, they fall in love.
"The girl in the book is like me. She's simple and moody," said Guiyeoni.
Guiyeoni's book doesn't only use words. It also uses things like emotions. Emotions are small icons, like smiling faces, and they are used to show emotions. Kids know what these things mean, because they often use them when they talk on the Internet or send messages with mobile phones.
Guiyeoni said she wrote this way because of her young readers. "Writing with pictures is vivid(生动)and can say a lot of things," she said.
Guiyeoni began writing the book's story on the Web in 2001 when she was a Senior 2 (高二)student. Last year, she put that online story together to make this book. "That Guy Was Cool" has been made into a film, and it will come out in Korea next month.
This is Guiyeoni's first of four books, and she hopes to keep writing as she goes through college.
She also has a message for young writers. "I think that if they try hard, lots of young people can do this."

questions.text: Guiyeoni is <blank> .

choices.A: a girl who falls in love with her classmate

questions.explanation: Guiyeoni is the author of "That Guy Was Cool."

questions.text: Which of the following may Not be an emotion?
questions.explanation: See you is a saying goodbye.

questions.text: The author used emotions to write the book because <blank> .

choices.B: she wants her young readers to be interested
choices.C: pictures can say lots of things
choices.D: she was only a Senior student when she was writing the story

questions.explanation: "Writing with pictures is vivid(生动)and can say a lot of things," she said.

questions.text: Which of the following sayings has the closest meaning to "I think that if they try hard, lots of young people can do this"?

choices.D: Where there is a will, there is a way.

questions.explanation: Where there is a will, there is a way means that if you are determined to do something, you will find a way to do it.

question_sets.context:
Mobile phone (手机) has become a problem for middle schools. Some middle schools in Australia have banned (禁止) students from carrying mobile phones during school hours.
Mobile phone use among children has become a problem for the school this year. Several children have got mobile phones as Christmas gifts, and more students will want them. Mary Bluett, an official, said mobile phone use is a distraction (分心的事) to students during school hours and it also gives teachers so much trouble in their classrooms. Teachers were also saying that sometimes students might use phone messages to cheat during exams.
She said some schools had tried to ban mobile phones. Some parents felt unhappy because they couldn't get in touch with their children.
Many teachers said students should not have mobile phones at school, but if there was a good reason, they could leave their phones at school office. They also said there were many reasons why the students should not have mobile phones at school: they were easy to lose and were a distraction from studies.
Many people say that they understand why parents would want their children to have phones, but they think schools should let the students know when they can use their mobile phones.

questions.text: We know from the passage that some children get mobile phones from <blank> .
questions.explanation: Several children have got mobile phones as Christmas gifts.

questions.text: What does the underlined word cheat mean in the passage?
questions.explanation: Cheat means to act dishonestly or unfairly in order to gain an advantage, especially in a game or examination.

questions.text: The passage tells us that <blank> .

choices.A: students shouldn't have mobile phones at school except for some special reasons
choices.B: it is impossible to ban students from using mobile phones at school
choices.C: some parents felt unhappy because they couldn't use their phones at school
choices.D: parents should teach their children how to use mobile phones during school hours

questions.explanation: Many teachers said students should not have mobile phones at school, but if there was a good reason, they could leave their phones at school office.

We stopped the car in front of the shop. An hour later we came back to the car, each of us carried a lot of things. Then the trouble started------We couldn't open the car door."Oh, dear," said my wife. "What are we going to do?" "Let's ask the policeman." I said. The policeman was very kind and was very glad to do. A few minutes later he got the door open. Just at the moment, an angry man came up and shouted, "What are you doing with my car?"

question_sets.context:
In England nobody under the age of eighteen is permitted to drink in a bar. Mr. Peter liked going to the bar near his house. But he never took his son, Mike, because he was too young. One day when Mike had his eighteenth birthday, Mr. Peter took him to the bar for the first time. They drank for about half an hour. And Mr. Peter said to his son, "now, Mike, I want to teach you something useful. You must always be careful not to drink too much. But how do you know that you have had enough? Well, I will tell you. Do you see those two lights at the end of the bar? When they become four, it means you have had too much, and you should go home."
"But, Dad," said Mike, "I can only see one light at the end of the bar, and do you think I am drinking too little?"

choices.C: not to drink more than enough

questions.explanation: Mr. Peter advised his son to be careful not to drink too much.

questions.explanation: Mike said he could only see one light at the end of the bar.

questions.text: This is <blank> time for Mike to drink in a bar.
questions.explanation: The passage states that Mr. Peter took Mike to the bar for the first time on his eighteenth birthday.

questions.text: Who drank too much?
questions.explanation: Mike's father drank too much, because he saw more lights than there actually were.

question_sets.context:
Dear Caroline ,
How is everything with you ? I'm sorry I didn't reply sooner. I'm as busy as a bee!
One thing is for sure: New York City is not Louisville. On one hand, there are good restaurants, many film theatres and concert halls .The public transport (运输)system is great. Also, there are so many different kinds of people .The other day , I saw three people walking down Broadway .They were wearing monkey costumes (装束)!
On the other hand , this is no small town .It's crowded, dirty and busy , busy , busy. It has rats(老鼠)! In New York ,there is one rat for every person. Well, I guess you have to take the good with the bad ,right?
All in all , work is quite good ,I take a train to the office. It takes about 20 minutes ---- not too bad. My job is challenging(挑战). I work more than I used to (过去), but there are some good chances for promotion(提升), so I think the hard work will be worth(值得) it .
Danny says hi . We both miss you , and the old coffee shop , and the disco….Mom is calling me for dinner , so I'd better end here. Write back soon !

choices.D: She has many things to do .

questions.explanation: The idiom "as busy as a bee" means very busy, with many tasks to do.

choices.B: Louisville has more rats than New York City

choices.D: New York City has more big-city problems than Louisville

questions.explanation: The passage implies that New York City is more crowded, dirty, and has more rats compared to Louisville.

questions.explanation: Annabella mentions that the hard work will be worth it because of the chance for promotion.

choices.C: They worked at the same company .
choices.D: They liked to walk along Broadway .

questions.explanation: The passage mentions that they miss the old coffee shop and the disco.

questions.text: What do we learn about Danny ?

choices.A: He takes a train to work.

questions.explanation: Danny sends his regards to Caroline through Annabella.

Too much dreaming can be harmful. The more we sleep,the longer we dream.The mind is hard at work when we dream .That is why we may have a long sleep and still wake up tired.

question_sets.context:
Long, long ago, there lived a rich man. He had a servant (仆人). He and the servant loved wine and good food very much. Each time the rich man left his home, the servant would drink the wine and eat up all the nice food in the house. The rich man knew what his servant did, but he had never caught his servant doing that.
One morning, when he left home, he said to the servant, "Here are two bottles of poison (毒药) and some nice food in the house. You must take off them." With these words, he went out.
But the servant knew that the rich man had said was untrue. After the rich man was away from his home, he enjoyed a nice meal. Because he drank too much, he was drunk and fell to the ground. When the rich man came back, he couldn't find his food and his wine. He became very angry. He woke the servant up. But the servant told his story very well. He said a cat had eaten up everything. He was afraid to be punished, so he drank the poison to kill himself.

choices.A: there was in fact poison in the bottles
choices.B: did not want the servant to drink his wine
choices.C: he wanted to kill the cat
choices.D: he wanted to kill the servant

questions.explanation: The rich man lied to the servant.

questions.text: In fact, ______ ate all the nice food and drank the wine.
questions.explanation: the servant would drink the wine and eat up all the nice food

questions.text: From the story, we know that the servant is very _______.
questions.explanation: The servant told his story very well
